abstract: Speech by high-ranking Mormon Church apostle Dallin Oaks in which he referred obliquely to Kentucky clerk Kim Davis and said person's religious beliefs do not allow them to disregard law is mark of how church is distancing itself from other religious conservatives who defended Davis; while church still opposes same-sex marriage, it appears to have adopted position of compromise.
lead_paragraph: Dallin Oaks, a leader in the Mormon Church, said that public officials like Kim Davis should follow the law and not apply their religious beliefs.

headline.main: Mormons Say Duty to Law on Same-Sex Marriage Trumps Faith
headline.print_headline: Mormons Say Duty to Law on Marriage Trumps Faith

snippet: Dallin Oaks, a leader in the Mormon Church, said that public officials like Kim Davis should follow the law and not apply their religious beliefs.

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)
